results.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
results.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

constellations_primary.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_primary.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

results.title_for_label: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
results.description: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
description_for_label: Though it was made in England, this projector made it over 15,000kms to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia. Situated on pastoral land in the Murray and Mellee region of South Australia, Koomooloo Station operated as a sheep station from 1868 and in 1951, this projector was bought to entertain workers during the shearing season. Luckily it has a vent at the back of the casing to keep it cool because if it was used inside a shearing shed the heat would’ve been insufferable.
results.credit_line_for_label: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → MI-04. Materiality → MI-04-C04

results.title: 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector
results.brief_description: Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector.

constellations_primary.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_primary.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

results.description:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!
description_for_label:
Carbon arc projectors use the first electric light ever invented. Arc lamps were commonly found in streetlamps during the 1870s, gradually replaced by incandescent light in the early 20th century. But in situations that called for a high-intensity light, like movie projectors, arc lamps still had a role.

Carbon arc projectors were common until WWII, and it’s rare to see one as late as the 1950s. Because of the intensity of the light in these projectors, they were mostly used in large auditoriums, despite being designed as a lightweight travelling projector. They were marketed as the best bet for screening 16mm film in tents, at road shows, at fairs in rural areas and outdoors – as long as there was a power source!

results.title: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.brief_description: The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F. Kennedy on camera in 1963.

constellations_primary.name: Papa-paparazzi
constellations_primary.description: Media attention and paparazzi from the assassination of JFK to Lady Gaga's music video.

results.title_for_label: Bell and Howell Zoomatic Director Series Model 414 PD
results.description: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.
description_for_label: Cameras can be used to record history, but they can also become part of it as well. The Bell and Howell Model is the same type of camera used by Abraham Zapruder, who was dubbed the first “citizen journalist” after he inadvertently captured the assassination of US President John F Kennedy on camera in 1963. The footage was sold to LIFE magazine, who printed it frame-by-frame, and became a key part of the FBI investigation. The increasing popularity of home movies led to the development of more affordable technology that was common in households just like the Bell and Howell Model.

results.title: Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR
results.brief_description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War.

constellations_primary.name: Conflict to cartoons
constellations_primary.description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera frequently used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War, but this Constellation goes to some much brighter places.

results.description: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War. Davis in particular, preferred this model due to its lightweight and dependable nature, namely in challenging environmental conditions like shooting on the frontline with South Vietnamese troops. Travelling light enabled Davis to become part of the action and blend seamlessly to show the world the harsh realities of what was actually happening on the ground in Vietnam. Combat photographers often carried several cameras, including a bulkier model with a separate sound recorder.
description_for_label: The Bell and Howell Filmo 70DR was a durable, 16mm camera used by combat photographers like Robert Capa during the Spanish Civil War and Australian Neil Davis in the Vietnam War. Davis in particular, preferred this model due to its lightweight and dependable nature, namely in challenging environmental conditions like shooting on the frontline with South Vietnamese troops. Travelling light enabled Davis to become part of the action and blend seamlessly to show the world the harsh realities of what was actually happening on the ground in Vietnam. Combat photographers often carried several cameras, including a bulkier model with a separate sound recorder.

results.title: Sony Betamovie BMC-100P
results.brief_description: This Sony Betamovie BMC-100P model of camera carried Betamax cassette tapes, which were introduced by Sony in 1975. It was the first consumer camcorder, including both camera and recorder in a single unit that would become standard in the years to follow.

constellations_primary.name: Found footage and the first camcorder
constellations_primary.description: Amateur filmmakers turned the camera on their own lives when camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P came on the market. The style of footage filmed on camcorders has inspired many fictional films, particularly in the horror genre.

results.description: The late 1970s to 1980s were a time of voracious competition and innovation for companies attempting to gain a monopoly on the growing home video market. This Sony Betamovie BMC-100P model of camera carried Betamax cassette tapes, which were introduced by Sony in 1975. It was the first consumer camcorder, including both camera and recorder in a single unit that would become standard in the years to follow. The rival Betamax and VHS (Video Home System) formats were incompatible with each other, meaning buyers had to choose. The advantages of Betamax were its slightly superior picture quality and smaller size, but the length of recording time was considerably shorter than VHS.
description_for_label: The late 1970s to 1980s were a time of voracious competition and innovation for companies attempting to gain a monopoly on the growing home video market. This Sony Betamovie BMC-100P model of camera carried Betamax cassette tapes, which were introduced by Sony in 1975. It was the first consumer camcorder, including both camera and recorder in a single unit that would become standard in the years to follow. The rival Betamax and VHS (Video Home System) formats were incompatible with each other, meaning buyers had to choose. The advantages of Betamax were its slightly superior picture quality and smaller size, but the length of recording time was considerably shorter than VHS.
